metadata.title: AI Peer Review Acceleration of LLM-Generated Glioblastoma Clinical Trial Patient Matching ML, FDA/ICH/ISO, and FastAPI
metadata.description:
Human peer review was an effective technique to address quality, originality, and errors of non-LLM generated work. Researcher-AI trust has since then grown due to performant large language model (LLM) benchmark improvements and author implementations across different model manufacturers for processing frequent, complex, and voluminous data. This single human-AI team has led to the emergence of readily available artificial intelligence peer review. A primary benefit of AI peer review is the ability to appropriately conduct iterative analyses and corrections throughout the entire manuscript process. This responsible method improves on over-worked and fatigued human recommendations provided after manuscript completion. Here, a maximum efficiency study was performed in 14 days with the author utilizing a prior glioblastoma clinical trial matching guidance and a TrialGPT paper as inputs to output a prompt for developing a Python deep learning pipeline. A 10 file dataset and clinical BERT model notebook were generated by Sonnet 4.5 Extended, followed by repetitions of code fixes and optimizations to yield a final notebook at a low test set performance of 67.3%. A triple AI peer review conducted by Sonnet, GPT 5.1, and Grok 4.1 all yielded the primary recommendation to upgrade to a tabular model, which was more suitable for the csv dataset.

ChatGPT then identified the most appropriate selection: an open source TabPFN-v2-clf model from Hugging Face. The Sonnet recommendations also included detailed instruction for five-fold cross-validation, SHAP explainability, and bias analysis incorporation. An AI peer review evaluation standard for ML workflows based criterion and efficiency metrics was generated by Opus 4.5 with highest efficiencies based on the least number of humans, prompts, and time at the lowest LLM cost. Subsequent evaluation of the current workflow with an overall quality of 87.5%, and 0.831 efficiency based on human, prompt, time, and cost metrics. The ChatGPT identified model and Sonnet review instructions were implemented into the prior notebook to yield a new notebook that saw an acceleration in research progress with a test set accuracy improvement to 94.0% with few-shot learning along with peer review corrections. A regulatory compliance prompt was created, followed by full document generations of FDA 21 CFR Part 820, ICH-GCP E6(R2), and ISO 14971 addressing quality, clinical practice, and risk management. Several attempts to create an effective FastAPI code repository by Sonnet were initially unsuccessful, however an Opus/Sonnet prompting strategy yielded a FastAPI interface with three successful glioblastoma patient clinical trial match predictions. AI as a senior software engineer and as a senior regulatory analyst were also employed as part of the AI peer review process

The purpose of this AI peer review study was to place the world’s focus back on innovating active and real world medical AI advancements in a fraction of the time. Measuring the effect AI implementation has on large workforces can be challenging to quantify. The conversational human-AI R&D relationship has become increasingly solitude: therefore this single author project should be viewed as the standard for new workflows going into the future. This next evolution of peer review is especially suitable for hard working researchers in less favorable economic, educational, and affiliation conditions, such as the author of the paper. This process is afforded by low cost, fast, and easy to use state of the art LLMs from Anthropic, Google, OpenAI, and xAI; marking the pivot away from slow and irresponsible use of human peer review for LLM-generated data, and back to fast automation of patient health applications at scale. Many authors of less influence can now improve their speed of development and gain reputation in papers by simply providing prompts, LLMs, AI peer review recommendations, and corrections they made - without the need for paid review or journals. Interested parties can then view the author’s peer review findings alongside the paper. Trust for the AI peer review process was established over a series of human-AI works reflected in LLM code and non-code benchmarking, applications in literature, and prior author works using AI in review roles coordinated across judging, external validation, cross-verification, meta-verification, and tests according to FDA/ICH guidance.

data.title: AI Peer Review Acceleration of LLM-Generated Glioblastoma Clinical Trial Patient Matching ML, FDA/ICH/ISO, and FastAPI

metadata.title: Establishment of a Strategic Financing Mechanism for Sustained Construction and Maintenance of Zambia's Public Roads-A Case for Lusaka District
metadata.description: Investment in physical infrastructure, such as roads, bridges, airports, sea ports, water ports, railways etc., is a fundamental ingredient in the growth and economic development of a country. Compared to countries like Singapore, South Korea and China, countries in Sub-Saharan Africa have significantly underinvested in infrastructure over the years, resulting in stunted growth. Zambia, which has a large infrastructure funding gap, and a ballooning government debt, cannot rely solely on the government to meet its infrastructure funding needs. This study looked at establishment of a strategic financing mechanism for sustained construction and maintenance of Zambia’s public roads- a case of Lusaka district. The study adopted pragmatism philosophy, focusing on practical, real-world outcomes. It combined quantitative and qualitative methods to address establishment of a strategic financing mechanism for sustained construction and maintenance of Zambia’s public roads (Tashakkori & Teddlie, 2010). A mixed-methods approach was used, integrating both qualitative and quantitative techniques. Qualitative methods (interviews, focus groups) explored strategic mechanism of sustained financing for construction and maintenance of Zambia’s public roads, while quantitative surveys measured ways of sustaining the financing for construction and maintenance of the public roads This approach provided a comprehensive understanding of how to have a strategic mechanism to fund the construction and maintenance of public roads in Zambia (Creswell & Plano Clark, 2017). The study applied both deductive and inductive approaches. Data collected was analysed using the Dedose Software for the qualitative part and for the quantitative part a thematic analysis was used to come up with the results. Zambia has in place legal and institutional frameworks (Tembo, 2015) that are necessary for effective and efficient road asset management. This study established that a number of financing strategies or frame works for road construction and maintenance such as RoadSIP 1 and II and RoadSIP III (yet to be launched), performed fairly well albeit some challenges. It also established that most road projects under implementation are under the government’s balance sheet and that, the Road sector’s indebtedness to local Contractors and Consultants was increasing and the financing gap was widening. Zambia would need to spend an average of $1.6 billion a year over the decade 2022–30 to develop the infrastructure found in the rest of the developing world (Foster and Dominguez, 2010). To close this financial gap required raising more funds and looking for more effective ways to meet infrastructure targets. The study established that since traditional funding methods for road construction and maintenance in Zambia such as tax revenues and loans are becoming unsustainable, there is need to look for other alternatives. The study established the potential strategic sources of funding for sustained construction and maintenance of Zambia’s public roads include public private partnerships, equity financing, road tolls and establishment of a State Infrastructure Bank(s). The study also established a Strategic Road Financing Framework (SRFFW) that clearly illustrates the interconnection between institutional governance, revenue diversification, community engagement, and sustainability. To Address financing challenges, it was recommended that there is need to increase Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs) by inviting the private sector to participate in the construction, maintenance, and financing of roads.
keywords: Road Construction and Maintenance, Strategic Funding, Private Public Partnerships, Inadequate Financing, Strategic Road Financing Framework.

journal.title: Journal of Economics, Finance And Management Studies

data.title: Establishment of a Strategic Financing Mechanism for Sustained Construction and Maintenance of Zambia's Public Roads-A Case for Lusaka District

metadata.title: Real-Time Phishing URL Detection Using Hybrid Machine Learning and Heuristic Analysis
metadata.description: Phishing sites still cause big problems online, often resulting in stolen money, leaked info, or fake identities being created. Older detection methods use only machine learning or fixed rules, which makes them less accurate and slow during live use. Instead, this study introduces a mixed approach combining smart algorithms with practical URL checks that work instantly. The system tests five types - Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, along with K-Nearest Neighbors - using a known public set of phishing links. A quick heuristic tool checks URL structure - then an advanced mix layer decides the outcome. Tests show this combined method beats single models by being more accurate and stable. On top of that, a live web app built with Streamlit lets users test any URL, complete with confidence levels and clear feature insights. The project boosts clarity, real-world use, and trust in spotting today's phishing attempts.
keywords: Phishing Detection, Machine Learning, URL Classification, Hybrid Model, Ensemble Learning, Cyber security, Streamlit, Heuristic Analysis
references: 1.	T. Swetha, S. M. Seshaiah, K. L. Hemalatha, S. V. N. Murthy and B. H. Manjunatha Kumar, "Hybrid Machine Learning Approach for Real-Time Malicious URL Detection Using SOM-RMO and RBFN with Tabu Search," VTU Research Publication, Karnataka, India, 2024.
2.	C. Do Xuan, H. D. Nguyen and V. N. Tisenko, "Malicious URL Detection Based on Machine Learning," Int. J. Adv. Computer Science and Applications (IJACSA), vol. 11, no. 1, pp. 101–108, 2020.

3.	C. Rupa, G. Srivastava, S. Bhattacharya, P. Reddy and T. R. Gadekallu, "A Machine Learning Driven Threat Intelligence System for Malicious URL Detection," in Proc. 16th Int. Conf. Availability, Reliability and Security, pp. 1-7, 2021.
4.	A. S. Raja, R. Vinodini and A. Kavitha, "Lexical Features Based Malicious URL Detection Using Machine Learning Techniques," Materials Today: Proceedings, vol. 47, pp. 163-166, 2021.
5.	M. Aljabri et al., "Detecting Malicious URLs Using Machine Learning Techniques: Review and Research Directions," IEEE Access, vol. 10, pp. 121395-121417, 2022.
6.	S. H. Ahammad et al., "Phishing URL Detection Using Machine Learning Methods," Advances in Engineering Software, vol. 173, p. 103288, 2022.

7.	S. Mythreya, A. S. D. Murthy, K. Saikumar and V. Rajesh, "Prediction and Prevention of Malicious URL Using ML and LR Techniques," in Handbook of Research on Technologies for E-Collaboration During Global Crises, pp. 302-315, IGI Global, 2022.
8.	B. Janet and A. Nikam, "Real-Time Malicious URL Detection on Twitch Using Machine Learning," in Proc. Int. Conf. Electronics and Renewable Systems (ICEARS), pp. 1185-1189, 2022.
9.	G. Pradeepa and R. Devi, "Review of Malicious URL Detection Using Machine Learning," in Soft Computing for Security Applications, Springer, pp. 97-105, 2022.
10.	A. Karim, M. Shahroz, K. Mustofa, S. B. Belhaouari and S. R. K. Joga, "Phishing Detection System Through Hybrid Machine Learning Based on URL," IEEE Access, vol. 11, pp. 36805-36822, 2023.

journal.title: Research and Reviews: Advancement in Cyber Security

data.title: Real-Time Phishing URL Detection Using Hybrid Machine Learning and Heuristic Analysis

metadata.title: Manim – Mathematical Animation Framework
metadata.description:
What's Changed

Breaking Changes and Deprecations

New Features

  • Introduce seed in random_color method to produce colors deterministically by @ishu9bansal in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4265
  • Add support for arithmetic operators //, %, *, ** and / on ValueTracker by @fmuenkel in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4351
  • Add TangentialArc mobject by @Brainsucker92 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4469

Fixed Bugs and Enhancements

  • Fix environment formating for Tex() mobject by @fmuenkel in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4159
  • Improved consistency of rate_function implementations by @BenKirkels in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4144
  • Make new Code mobject compatible with OpenGL renderer by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4164
  • Fix HSL color ordering in ManimColor by @thehugwizard in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4202
  • Fix return type of Polygram.get_vertex_groups() and rename variables in .round_corners() by @chopan050 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4063
  • Improve Mobject.align_data docstring by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4152
  • Fix :meth:VMobject.pointwise_become_partial failing when vmobject is self by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4193
  • Fix add_points_as_corners not connecting single point to existing path by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4219
  • Complete typing for logger_utils.py by @fmuenkel in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4134
  • Fix(graph): Allow any Line subclass as edge_type in Graph/DiGraph by @Akshat-Mishra-py in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4251
  • Replace exceptions, remove unused parameters, and fix type hints in Animation, ShowPartial, Create, ShowPassingFlash, and DrawBorderThenFill by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4214
  • Fix: Axes submobject colors are not being set properly by @ishu9bansal in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4291
  • Refactor Rotating and add docstrings to Mobject.rotate() and Rotating by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4147
  • Fix default config of manim init project to use correct pixel_height and pixel_width by @StevenH34 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4213
  • Handle opacity and transparent images by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4313
  • Gracefully fall back when version metadata is missing by @mohiuddin-khan-shiam in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4324
  • Fix for issue 4255 - Do not clear points when the number of curves is zero by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4320
  • Use utf-8 encoding to read generated .tex files. by @OliverStrait in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4334
  • Add zero to vmobject points to remove negative zeros in get_mobject_key by @elshorbagyx in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4332
  • Ensure stroke_width attribute of SVGMobject is not set to None by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4319
  • Fix Prism incorrectly rendering with dimensions=[2, 2, 2] in OpenGL by @ra1u in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4003
  • Fix BraceLabel.change_label() and document BraceText by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4347
  • Include Text.gradient in hash to properly regenerate Text when its gradient changes by @AbhilashaTandon in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4099
  • Fixed surface animations in OpenGL by @nubDotDev in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4286
  • Add type hints and support for arithmetic operators + and - on ValueTracker by @fmuenkel in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4129
  • Fix duplicate references in Scene.mobjects after ReplacementTransform with existing target mobject by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4242
  • Optimize always_redraw() by reducing Mobject copying in Mobject.become() by @chopan050 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4357
  • Enhance manim cfg show output and add info-level logging for config files read by @xnov18 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4375
  • Let Cube use Bevel type line joints by @nubDotDev in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4361
  • Properly define init_points methods for use in OpenGL instead of defining init_points = generate_points by @chopan050 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4360
  • Allow passing a tuple to buff in SurroundingRectangle to specify buffer in x and y direction independently by @nubDotDev in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4390
  • Rewrite color_gradient to always return a list of ManimColors by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4380
  • Ensure leading whitespace does not change line height for lines in CodeMobject by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4392
  • Simplify the function remove_invisible_chars in text_mobject.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4394
  • Fix some config options specified via --config_file not being respected properly by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4401
  • Fix: Correct resolution tuple order to (height, width) by @Nikhil172913832 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4440
  • Ensure that start and end points are stored as float values in Line3D by @SirJamesClarkMaxwell in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4080
  • OpenGL: Fix iterated nesting in DecimalNumber.set_value by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4373
  • Update default resolution in CLI to match Manim's 1920x1080 default settings by @SASHAKT1290 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4452
  • Better parsing of color styles in CodeMobject by @SirJamesClarkMaxwell in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4454
  • Allow selection of all scenes to render using '*' by @NightyStudios in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4470
  • Prevent mutation of about_point in apply_points_function_about_point by @Morkunas in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4478
  • Fix behavior of Mobject.suspend_updating: when only suspending parent mobject, let children continue updating by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4402
  • Allow passing a buff to LabeledDot by @nubDotDev in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4403
  • Pass ndarrays to mapbox_earcut.triangulate_float32() to fix TypeError in mapbox_earcut==2.0.0 by @GuiCT in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4479
  • Fix duplicated arrow tips in DashedVMobject (issue #3220) by @jakekinchen in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4484

Documentation

  • Add docstring to :meth:.Mobject.get_family by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4127
  • Fix link formatting and clarify the distinction between Manim versions in index.rst by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4131
  • Add instructions for installing system utilities cairo and pkg-config via Homebrew on MacOS by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4146
  • Add missing line break in Code of Conduct's conflict of interest policy by @Hasan-Mesbaul-Ali-Taher in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4185
  • Fix links to Pango website by @ragibson in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4217
  • Replace poetry with uv in the README by @xinoehp512 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4226
  • Improve docstring for interpolate method in Mobject class by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4149
  • Add docstrings to Line and remove None handling for path_arc parameter by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4223
  • Add docstring to :meth:Mobject.family_members_with_points by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4128
  • Update incorrect docstring for :attr:ManimConfig.gui_location property by @SAYAN02-DEV in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4254
  • Fix formatting of color space documentation by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4274
  • Enhance and Paraphrase Description of ManimCE in README.md by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4141
  • docs: add explanation about the rate_func in the custom animation by @pedropxoto in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4278
  • Fixed artifact in docstring of Animation by @barollet in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4283
  • Rename update function dot_position to update_label in .add_updater example by @irvanalhaq9 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4196
  • Fix Microsoft typo in TexFontTemplateLibrary scene in example_scenes/advanced_tex_fonts.py by @alterdim in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4305
  • Improved readability, grammar, as well as added docstrings for consistency by @NASAnerd05 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4267
  • Add docstrings for ChangingDecimal and ChangeDecimalToValue by @haveheartt in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4346
  • Fix Sphinx exceptions when trying to build documentation via latex / as pdf by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4370
  • Added license information to documentation landing page by @Nikil-D-Gr8 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/3986
  • Set the default Python version to 3.13 in the uv installation guide by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4480

Maintenance and Testing

  • Change project management tool from poetry to uv by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4138
  • Re-add ffmpeg as dependency within Docker image by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4150
  • Add tests for Matrix, DecimalMatrix, IntegerMatrix by @pdrzan in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4279
  • Add tests for polylabel utility by @giolucasd in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4269
  • Add support for pycodestyle W rule in Ruff by @KaiqueDultra in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4276
  • Fix files with few MyPy typing errors by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4263
  • Explicitly mention all files that mypy should ignore in the mypy.ini configuration file by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4306
  • Remove dead code from scene.py and vector_space_scene.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4310
  • Add type annotations to scene.py and vector_space_scene.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4260
  • Replace setup-texlive-action in CI workflow by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4326
  • Adding type annotations to polyhedra.py and matrix.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4322
  • Handling typing errors in text/numbers.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4317
  • Move configure_pygui into a Scene method and remove manim.gui by @chopan050 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4314
  • Add typing annotations to svg_mobject.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4318
  • Add type annotations to mobject/svg/brace.py and default to label_constructor=Text in BraceText by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4309
  • Add classes MethodWithArgs, SceneInteractContinue and SceneInteractRerun inside new module manim.data_structures by @chopan050 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4315
  • Fix typo in import of OpenGLCamera in utils/hashing.py by @fmuenkel in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4352
  • Add type annotations to manim/renderer/shader.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4350
  • Add type annotations to tex_mobject.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4355
  • Add type annotations to three_d_camera.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4356
  • Revert change of default value for tex_environment by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4358
  • Add type hints to scene_file_writer.py, section.py, and zoomed_scene.py by @fmuenkel in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4133
  • Add type annotations for most of camera and mobject.graphing by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4125
  • Add VectorNDLike type aliases by @chopan050 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4068
  • Add type annotations to dot_cloud.py, vectorized_mobject_rendering.py and opengl_three_dimensions.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4359
  • Add type annotations to indication.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4367
  • Add type annotations to composition.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4366
  • Add type annotations to growing.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4368
  • Add type annotations to movement.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4371
  • Exclude check for cyclic imports by CodeQL by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4384
  • Refactor imports from collections.abc, typing and typing_extensions for Python 3.9 by @chopan050 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4353
  • Add type annotations to opengl_renderer_window.py by @fmuenkel in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4363
  • Rename SceneFileWriter.save_final_image() to save_image() by @fmuenkel in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4378
  • Add type annotations to text_mobject.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4381
  • Rename types like RGBA_Array_Float to FloatRGBA and add types like FloatRGBA_Array by @chopan050 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4386
  • Add type annotations to opengl_geometry.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4396
  • Add type annotations to moving_camera.py by @henrikmidtiby in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4397
  • Add type annotations to opengl_mobject.py by @RBerga06 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4398
  • Fix failing pre-commit tests by @cclauss in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4434
  • Add type annotations to cairo_renderer.py by @fmuenkel in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4393
  • Fix type errors and add typings for Mobject.apply_function(), its derivatives, and other utility functions by @godalming123 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4228
  • Bump macOS image from deprecated macos-13 to macos-15-intel by @chopan050 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4481
  • Prepare new release v0.19.1 and bump minimum required Python version to 3.10 by @behackl in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4490

Dependency Version Changes

  • Bump typing extensions minimum version by @JasonGrace2282 in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4121
  • [pre-commit.ci] pre-commit autoupdate by @pre-commit-ci[bot] in https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4122

metadata.notes: We acknowledge the importance of good software to support research, and we note that research becomes more valuable when it is communicated effectively. To demonstrate the value of Manim, we ask that you cite Manim in your work.

metadata.title: applied-geodesy/jag3d: JAG3Dv20251201
metadata.description:
JAG3D & modules

  • To avoid conflicts with invalid UNC paths, the JAVA object File has been replaced by Path, cf. https://software.applied-geodesy.org/forum/?id=14918
  • Missing entries in i18n translation files have been added

International Course on Engineering Surveying 2026

The method of least-squares developed by Gauss is one of the most important analytical tools in geodesy and metrology for ensuring accurate and reliable data analysis and results. In modern engineering geodesy, it plays a crucial role in analyzing both planned and existing geodetic networks as well as in verifying their congruence. Beside the coordinates of a network, the method provides the dispersion of the estimated parameters and essential quantities for quality evaluation.

At the 21th International Course on Engineering Surveying, the principles of geodetic network adjustment are recapitulated within the specific tutorial named network analysis. The conference will be held at TU Graz from February 10 to 13, 2026 - save the date. The network analysis tutorial offers a practical introduction to the fundamentals of adjustment calculations. Through guided case studies, participants will explore how adjustment methods work and gain a deeper understanding of the key parameters involved. Based on this knowledge, the congruence of networks is evaluated within the framework of deformation analysis. Moreover, the tutorial demonstrates how the adjustment results can be integrated into existing workflows and further processed. For the practical part, the powerful open source least-squares software package Java·Applied·Geodesy·3D is used.

Join fellow users, get hands-on experience with JAG3D, get directly in touch with the developer, and expand your professional network during the Course on Engineering Surveying. See you soon in Graz!

metadata.title: KEY TO REPORTING PLS-SEM RESULTS
metadata.description: Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) is predicated on the establishment of a causal relationship between endogenous and exogenous latent variables by measuring them with the help of indicators. These causal relationships, established on the basis of extant literature, are represented by a proposed research model, and hypotheses are designed and tested simultaneously. This method is usually analysed using covariance-based (CB-SEM) and variance-based (PLS-SEM) approaches. In numerous academic studies, the dominant approach for fitting and hypothesis testing of research models describing the relationships between latent variables has been the use of LISREL and AMOS software for covariance-based structural equation modelling. In recent years, there has been increase in the number of papers in which SEM analyses are performed with the PLS-SEM approach compared to CB-SEM. The present study commences with a discussion of CB-SEM and PLS-SEM, followed by the provision of straightforward and pragmatic guidance on the presentation of results in the context of PLS-SEM analysis, which constitutes the primary focus of the study. The paper initiates with an examination of the rationale behind the utilisation of PLS-SEM, subsequently offering a concise overview of the fundamental principles for the reporting of PLS-SEM outcomes. The paper also provides a brief overview of the basic concepts of sample size, assumptions, model predictive power, Importance-Performance Map (IPMA) and moderating in PLS-SEM.

journal.title: Structural Equation Modelling and Multivariate Research

metadata.title: Case studies in autonomous home robotics: Real-world applications of spatial computing
metadata.description: Domestic robots frequently fail to navigate and adapt in complex home environments, leading to reduced reliability and increased user intervention. We introduce an integrated spatial computing architecture that combines multi-modal sensor fusion with semantic mapping to achieve a 94% success rate in dynamic obstacle avoidance and 95% coverage accuracy in household navigation. Our system demonstrates breakthrough capabilities in real-time environmental adaptation through a novel three-tier processing pipeline: enhanced sensor fusion that maintains position accuracy within 1.8 centimeters, semantic-aware mapping that reduces computational overhead by 76%, and context-driven navigation that decreases user intervention requirements by 78%. The implementation results show sustained performance across varying lighting conditions, with response times averaging 85 milliseconds and operational reliability reaching 99.2% under normal household conditions. These advances in spatial computing capabilities enable autonomous robots to operate more effectively in dynamic domestic settings while maintaining robust performance across diverse environmental challenges.

creators.name: Srivastava, Prashant Anand
creators.affiliation: Senior Software Engineer at Amazon Lab126, CA.

journal.title: Global Journal of Engineering and Technology Advances

data.title: Case studies in autonomous home robotics: Real-world applications of spatial computing

metadata.title: HERALD: High-resolution Early Recognition of Antigenic Landscape Divergence
metadata.description:
HERALD: High-resolution Early Recognition of Antigenic Landscape Divergence

A theoretical framework for geometry-based viral surveillance that enables early detection of immune-escape variants before widespread transmission. HERALD constructs a Riemannian pullback manifold where Euclidean distances in latent space approximate antigenic relationships within bounded-distortion regimes.

This deposit includes:

* Complete theoretical framework (manuscript)
* Empirical validation studies on SARS-CoV-2 data:
  - Validation I (DMS): Demonstrates 5.7–8.8× improvement in geometric separation over baseline methods on deep mutational scanning escape data across multiple antibody conditions
  - Validation II-A (Time Traveler): Retrospective time-slice replay on Nextstrain genomic surveillance data; frozen encoder trained only on 2020 DMS data detects Omicron BA.1 emergence in South Africa (Z = 2.29, p ≈ 0.011) with near-zero support-adjusted latency
  - Validation II-B (Instrument Integrity): Audits structural soundness of the HERALD instrument—confirms PIT-normalized drift scores behave as calibrated Z-scores, validates threshold selection via synthetic Design Frontier analysis, and demonstrates geometric fidelity via Hamming stress test (r > 0.99 linearity up to 30 mutations)
* Frozen encoder checkpoint (herald_dms_encoder.pt) for reproducibility
* Validation code, results CSVs, and visualization plots (distance histograms, traffic-light heatmaps, Design Frontier curves, manifold smoothness plots)

Key Contributions:

  • Manifold Construction: Defines a contrastive learning objective with Jacobian/Laplacian regularization that induces smooth pullback metrics, enabling Euclidean computations to approximate geodesic distances reflecting antigenic divergence

  • Real-Time Drift Detection: Specifies a probability-integral transform (PIT) fusion scheme combining sequence, antigenic, and structural signals into a scalar drift statistic with O(log n) amortized complexity

  • Formal Guarantees: Derives margin-to-separation results for InfoNCE objectives and establishes Cantelli-based probability bounds requiring only finite variance (no sub-Gaussian assumptions), composing into conditional end-to-end dominance bounds with explicit error budgets

  • Evaluation Protocols: Provides falsifiable protocols for retrospective time-slice replay, prospective streaming emulation, distortion audits, and equity/parity analysis across pathogens (SARS-CoV-2, influenza, HIV)

  • Ethics Framework: Includes comprehensive governance templates addressing dual-use risks, information hazards, data sovereignty, abstention policies, and oversight structures

  • Empirical Validation: Validation I demonstrates 5.7–8.8× improvement in geometric separation (Δ) over baseline methods on SARS-CoV-2 deep mutational scanning data. Validation II confirms out-of-time generalization: the frozen encoder detects Omicron BA.1 emergence in South Africa (Z = 2.29, p ≈ 0.011) under sparse monthly surveillance data with near-zero support-adjusted latency.

Scope: The theoretical manuscript presents definitions, assumptions, theorems, and evaluation protocols. Validation I provides empirical confirmation on historical DMS data; Validation II demonstrates real-world surveillance applicability via retrospective time-slice replay on Nextstrain genomic data. Both studies use rigorous train/test methodology and no sequence optimization (safe surveillance scope). Applications extend beyond viral surveillance to bacterial pathogen monitoring (STEC, antibiotic resistance) where antigenic/functional divergence precedes clinical detection.

Author: Bee Rosa Davis (NASA Mission Systems Engineer, IBM X-Force Red Principal Adversarial Intelligence Engineer)

Keywords: viral surveillance, Riemannian geometry, contrastive learning, immune escape, early warning systems, algorithmic epidemiology, information geometry, public health AI, ESM-2, protein language models, deep mutational scanning

This copyright license does NOT grant any rights under patent law. Implementation, commercial use, or deployment of the HERALD framework may require separate patent licensing arrangements.

The patent covers the technical implementation of the framework. For research and educational use, no patent license is required. For commercial deployment or production systems, contact the inventor regarding patent licensing.

Version 3.0: Added Validation Study II ("Time Traveler") demonstrating out-of-time generalization—frozen geometry trained on 2020 DMS data detects 2022 Omicron emergence with p ≈ 0.011 under sparse surveillance conditions. Includes time-slice replay code, heatmaps, and frozen encoder checkpoint.

data.title: HERALD: High-resolution Early Recognition of Antigenic Landscape Divergence
